title: What was George Harrison’s signature guitar sound? - Quora

response.answer_text: George’s sound evolved over the years, but his most distinctive sound is his slide guitar work. There was some slide on Yer Blues on the White Album, but George seems to have perfected slide guitar when he worked with Delanie and Bonnie in 1969. He played on some really fine slide guitar songs in the 70′s. For You Blue  Give Me Love  Day After Day— George playing with Badfinger  Isn’t It A Pity  Cheer Down— from the 80’s  Leave A Light On For Me — on Belinda Carlisle’s single in the 90’s  Free as a Bird— George in the 21st century with The Beatles

Keith Richards often said George Harrison had a thin guitar sound. BUT Richards is rarely complimentary of others; a grumpy old man at times. I don’t think George had a signature sound. He went from very clean Gretsch / Vox combinations to a 12 string Rickenback… Gibson SG with Fuzz… Slide (which was more Hawaiian sounding than country & western). Harrison was a musican tinkerer. If anything his signature sound would be his use of naughty chords (dominant diminished chords and augmented chords) heard on songs like I Need You.
